I decided to update my review, as I have learned a lot since I originally posted it. Right off the bat, I just want to say it is painfully clear that the reason for most of the negative reviews is, "It's not Tekken 7." Ok, so go play Tekken 7, it's right there.

With that out of the way, I want to address the actual issues I have with the game, the biggest of which isn't a problem with the game itself- it's the monetization.
There is no reason why a game that costs $60 should have paid DLC characters, with the exception of crossovers; and crossover characters should absolutely NOT be stronger than originals (*cough*Clyde*cough*). I got the game at an 85% discount, but this is a valid excuse for a negative review.
The second issue I have is with how weak defense feels in relation to damage output. It feels like characters do way too much damage across the board. It's not a case of "if everyone is OP, nobody is." It's genuinely boring, because the matches feel rushed. I don't feel accomplished pressing one button to initiate a heat chain, just to follow it up with a combo that ends the round. It's not even annoying when it happens to me- it's just a really stupid mechanic. The craziest part is, I started playing AFTER they increased the max HP to 200. They need to either nerf damage across the board, or get rid of Heat chains.

Despite that major gripe I have, the good outweighs the bad. For starters, the graphics are absolutely stunning, especially for this genre. The amount of detail in the character models and environment are genuinely beautiful, and it adds a special level of immersion.
Next thing I really like is the Rage Art mechanic. It can completely change the outcome of a match, and it adds a level of strategy to both offense and defense that is genuinely exciting.
The Ghost Battle features are incredible. Wanna practice against that guy that just destroyed you in a set? Download his ghost data and go to town. Wanna fight YOURSELF? Pick one of your own ghosts and smash your monitor after you lose to yourself. The AI learning is really f*cking cool, and it will help you improve.
The replay system is another strong-suit. Can't figure out why you lost that match? Watch the replay and the game will pause it and tell you what you could have done differently at any given moment.
I could keep going on and on about features like this, from learning combos, to a full blown story mode, the offline content is plentiful AND worthwhile.
Online is obviously why most people are going to buy it. The rollback netcode is great, the ranked grind is fun, and the Fight Lounge is actually really cool, and a great place to socialize in a PlayStation Home kinda way.
Also, boobs. Can't forget about boobs.

A breath of fresh air, just like the arrival of Tekken 3. A considerable leap forward in terms of graphics (developed using Unreal Engine 5), the rebirth of inherited mechanics revisited with more aggression, and a very powerful sound design. But above all, veterans will tell you that this game is completely different from previous instalments: gameplay that doesn't necessarily focus on punishment, but rather on gaining the upper hand through oppression, mix-ups (guessing the next move) and stances. Fans of the franchise will be delighted by the Story mode, which includes numerous references, and as a bonus, the Tekken Ball mode, which makes its return 26 years later. There are now additional quests to complete the story with the second season.
For online competition, you'll need to hang in there: Tekken is not an easy game to get to grips with, even with the basic knowledge required. You can get by, but keep in mind that progress can be very slow. It's still a legacy game. My advice: have fun without stressing yourself out, otherwise the fun may come from studying the fundamentals, and there's no way around that step.

Tekken 8 is a competitive 3D fighting game that advances the long-running series with refined mechanics, aggressive pacing, and a strong focus on character individuality. Built on Unreal Engine 5, it delivers high visual fidelity and fluid animations that enhance both readability and impact during matches. The game maintains Tekken‚Äôs core movement system while introducing new features designed to make offense more rewarding and dynamic.

The narrative continues the Mishima family conflict, centering on Jin Kazama‚Äôs confrontation with Kazuya. The story mode blends cinematic sequences with playable segments, emphasizing dramatic stakes and character motivations. While the plot follows familiar themes of power, legacy, and revenge, its presentation benefits from improved visuals and more cohesive mission structure.

Combat remains deeply technical but leans further toward forward pressure. The Heat system is the centerpiece, granting characters temporary offensive boosts that expand combo routes, extend pressure, and enable new strategic layers. Rage Arts return as cinematic finishers, giving matches dramatic closing moments. Movement precision, punishment knowledge, and matchup awareness remain essential to high-level play.

The roster showcases a mix of returning favorites and newcomers, each with unique mechanics, stances, or signature techniques. Characters feel distinct without losing cohesiveness within the core system. Updates to move lists and animations improve clarity, allowing players to better recognize threats and react during fast exchanges. Customization options expand visual variety without affecting balance.

Online functionality features rollback netcode and a lobby system designed for smooth matchmaking. Ranked, quick match, and group play modes support competitive engagement, while training tools offer detailed frame data, scenario recording, and character guides. These resources make the game more approachable for new players without diluting its competitive depth.

Presentation is a major highlight. Detailed character models, dynamic stages, and impactful hit effects contribute to a more visceral sense of combat. The soundtrack blends electronic, rock, and thematic stage tracks to match the intensity of matches and narrative tone. Visual clarity during high-speed sequences helps maintain focus despite the increased aggression of the new mechanics.

Tekken 8 succeeds by modernizing the series with an offense-oriented system, robust online features, and high production values. It preserves the strategic complexity that defines Tekken while offering tools and mechanics that encourage more active play. For veterans and newcomers seeking a refined, high-intensity 3D fighter, it stands as one of the most polished entries in the franchise.

A very good TEKKEN game with some major flaws that let it down.

One of the major flaws being that the game is way too offensive now. Playing it smart and safe is dis-encouraged, and sometimes you are forced into unwinnable or near-impossible 50/50s purely due to pressure and the fact that you usually have to do some sort of maneuver to get out of the situation, leaving you vulnerable.

Even worse is the disgustingly advantageous Special Styles. While I understand that, in higher ranks, this is quite counterable and not much of an issue (if it gets used at all), it can really unbalance the lower ranks and lower the skill gaps meaning a beginner with Special Style and a decent idea of the game's mechanics has an advantage over someone who prefers not to use it. This would be all right as an optional feature - but it is allowed in RANKED, with no option to filter it out!

The heat system is MEH, I wouldn't care if it was removed altogether but I haven't ever found it game-breaking or grossly unbalanced. I especially like the risk/reward factor that the Rage Arts bring to the game. And they are great to look at, although they can drag on sometimes.

I feel this is why this game has become controversial amongst TEKKEN fans, mostly the competitive high-rank players. But I don't think this is so much the case for more casual or semi-serious players. The game offers plenty of Online and Offline content and doesn't feel unfinished.

What the game partially lacks in substance it makes up for in style. TEKKEN 8 is by far the best looking TEKKEN game I have ever played. The character models look outstanding, the stages are gorgeous, and the amount of detail in ever corner of the game graphically is impressive. The visual effects during fights are maybe a little overdone, but it definitely looks flashy, and it feels responsive.

I would recommend this game GENERALLY but there are some very major flaws that need to be ironed out. I can definitely understand people's point of view with the glaring issues in the game. If you are buying purely for story content and offline modes, there is a lot to be enjoyed. If you are a ranked player who is fairly competitive and high rank, and you are coming from a previous TEKKEN, do not set your expectations too high.

I've played Tekken since the 90's so I know the game well. This game is divisive among Tekken veterans because the defensive play has been nerfed, & generally the game is aiming to attract new players with flashier presentation & a focus on offensive pressure. In my opinion the game is best enjoyed with friends, or in "group" matches. Find players of similar skill & have fun. Ranked is not fun. At best it's 3 sets, but often an opponent will quit the match if they're losing bad or about to get a demotion. This even happens at intermediate ranks (where I stopped after around 120 ranked matches in over 1000 hours played). That & there are players running cheat scripts to auto duck, auto parry etc.
What I like is that the game has a very good training lab- so there's no excuses for not improving your game. I'll always enjoy Tekken as a lifelong fan, but I understand at high level play there are some frustrations that are taking a long time to correct.

I like Tekken 8, and honestly enjoy the "guessing" "50/50" aspect of the game others are talking about. When you've battled a character enough times to be able to predict their next move, it's quite satisfying, even if it is a 50/50 guess. It also feels accomplishing to finally consistently pull off a combo or move you've been struggling with for a while. I really enjoy the gameplay. However, I do agree with the other reviews here: the micro-transactions/DLCs are too much. Way too many characters and stages are locked behind a paywall, which can make it difficult to fully practice for tournaments if you're in the e-sports scene. We did not have this problem back in Tekken 6. $110 for the full game is crazy.

Hi steam welcome to my personal blog. I haven't really played Tekken since Tekken 2 and 3 so my knowledge of the game is limited to those titles, so this review will be from that perspective, my friends who I played with also had not touched Tekken since 4 or 5, mostly playing locally.

Tekken 8 is a lot different than the earlier games, it is nostalgic seeing old characters* but they have changed visually, it is still great to see them again though in new and revived forms; and this game is visually impressive and runs well enough. 

The gameplay is different in that it's not all about memorising moves and spacing, since now they have an easy mode that you can press that spams out moves and combos for you, again we all agreed not to use this, new players will bear the brunt of and with this feaure though.

There is also now heat and heat smashes, basically a limited resource per round that lets you do extra moves, more damage, or press a button that uses up all heat but performs an instant combo deleting a portion of the opponents health if it lands, again, not something we were proud of using but you get to smirk at them when it lands.

The least proud button that we didn't want to put people through (Or at least the animations are quite novel and cool to watch the first time around) is something called Rage, basically if you are low health you can press "the funny button", if this single strike hit lands the opponent has to watch as you perform a 20 second long cutscene that will remove over half of their health. Usually these don't land but if they do, boy they are going to *love* you so much.

*Ah yes, the asterix, under characters...Yes charging players money for characters that are classically base game characters, they themselves being replaced mostly by characters that bore me or I haven't heard of, a lot of the roster was hit or miss for me but this is personal preference, there are definitely some new favourites of mine in tekken 8. 

This game is heavy on the Item store, it will pop up every time you launch the game begging you to interact with the store, dlc and economy, in fact they released heihachi (An absolute Tekken staple) as DLC even though cannonically he was killed or something? That's fine, maybe? They advertised him in a youtube video which came with a cool map, whatever. Oh, god, the price...

...Except you pay seperately for the map...Then you also pay for the character, they advertised them together so as to seem they are related, how, neat? This goes on and on. It's greedy. Traditionally core characters should not be DLC in my opinion, or they should not release for this title at all. But that's not my decision.

I tried multiplayer for a bit, you know I work, I do other things. Apparently these people who I play against don't so I didn't bother playing against them that much. With that said there are other things you can do offline in Tekken so I applaud that, although the Singleplayer campaign is basically "I hope you're a Jin main!".

Picked up Tekken 8 just the funny customization options, stayed because of Clive, dropped it because of how bad it feels to play. They toned down defensive play to force more aggressive matches, but in doing so almost punishes trying to be aggressive while keeping a decent defense. Hitboxes/hurtboxes that are either way too large than they need to be, moves tracking people on whiff, absolutely insane interactions with not just the stage(s), but also the camera, a whole season of no real changes/fixes/balancing for the sake of tournament events when the game badly needs it... 

So much feels sacrificed for the beginner Tekken player experience, but being said beginner player (I have under 40 hours in Tekken 7 and one (1) in Tekken Tag 2) and playing more/getting better, it just feels awful to play. The "hehe funny 50/50 gamble" stops being funny when you're forced into coin-tosses every match, where losing the toss results in a combo that lasts so long you may as well be watching a cutscene. Characters with parries (shout-out my goat Clive) can parry some things, but other things break it, and it feels downright arbitrary as to why. Ditto to armored moves: some armored moves just break others for no reason other than "because why not". Getting hit by moves that are nowhere near you because the hitboxes in this game are absolutely massive for no reason other than... what, to make spectating more interesting? To make rounds end faster? Get a grip.

It's a fun game if you just run private matches with friends, and the character customization ([i]when it isn't locked behind a paywall[/i]) is neat (unless you play Kuma or Panda, in which case I'm so sorry), but other than that? Tekken 8 just feels like all style, no substance.
